section.title: Available Mobile UI Components
section.para: TouchKit introduces a number of components special to mobile device user interfaces.

The NavigationView is a layout component that consists of a NavigationBar and a content area. The content area is scrollable, so there is no need to use an inner panel component. In addition, there can be an optional toolbar component at the bottom of the view.

The navigation bar is a NavigationBar component, which is described in . You can get it with getNavigationBar() to access its manipulator methods. NavigationView also offers some shorthand methods: setNavigationBarComponent(), setLeftNavigationBarComponent(), getPreviousComponent(), setPreviousComponent(), and a setter and getter for the caption.
The optional toolbar is located at the bottom of the view. It can be any component, typically a HorizontalLayout or CssLayout with Buttons in it. You set the toolbar component with setToolbar().
The layout has a full size by default. The content are is expanding, so that it takes all the space left over from the navigation bar and toolbar.

The NavigationPanel is visual effect component that gives sliding animation when switching between views. This is done by registering three different components in the panel: the currently displayed and the previous and next component. You can set these components with setCurrentComponent(), setPreviousComponent(), and setNextComponent(), respectively.

The Toolbar is a horizontal layout, usually containing Button components. The toolbar has by default 100% horizontal width and fixed 40 pixel height, which is common in many mobile devices. The buttons are spread evenly in the horizontal direction.
Toolbar is typically used in a NavigationView, as described in .
The Toolbar has v-toolbar CSS style name.

The EmailField is just like the regular TextField, except that it has automatic capitalization and correction turned off. Mobile devices also recognize the field as an email field and can offer a virtual keyboard for the purpose, so that it includes the at (@) and period (.) characters, and possibly a shorthand for .com.

The NumberField is just like the regular TextField, except that it is marked as a numeric input field for mobile devices, so that they will show a numeric virtual keyboard rather than the default alphanumeric.
